content: Intelligence officials and Members of Congress are discussing ways to reduce intelligence spending while protecting core capabilities. DNI James R. Clapper Jr. warned that sequestration could lead to a 7% cut, or roughly $4 billion, to the National Intelligence Program budget, resulting in reduced global coverage and intelligence collection. He also highlighted the negative impact of budget cuts in the 1990s, which led to a distorted intelligence workforce with a lack of mid-level professionals. Congress completed action on the FY2013 intelligence authorization legislation (S. 3454). The FY2013 intelligence authorization legislation (S. 3454) was completed by Congress in December 2012. The bill reflected funding above the President's request but below the $53.9 billion appropriated for FY2012. This legislation followed the significant increase in intelligence budgets and reorganization of the intelligence community after the 9/11 attacks. The Intelligence Reform Act of 2004 (P.L. 108-458) established the Director of National Intelligence to oversee the intelligence community, advise the President, and coordinate intelligence efforts. This was in response to the 9/11 Commission's findings of inadequate coordination within the intelligence community. The 9/11 Commission's report in 2004 led to the establishment of the Director of National Intelligence to improve coordination within the intelligence community. Congress debated the recommendations, focusing on the DNI's authorities and budgeting for technical collection systems. Many of the Commission's recommendations were adopted with a compromise provision to respect department heads' statutory authorities. The intelligence community, as defined by 50 U.S.C. 401a(4), includes various agencies such as the CIA, DIA, NSA, NRO, NGA, FBI, Army Intelligence, Navy Intelligence, Air Force Intelligence, Marine Corps Intelligence, and Coast Guard Intelligence. Other offices like the Office of Intelligence and Analysis in the Department of the Treasury and the Office of National Security Intelligence in the Department of Energy are also part of this community.
